Journeys to Health—Healthcare in Africa</title><body_text>Need a doctor? In rural Africa, the nearest clinic can be days away. On average, families walk six kilometres for care, and some nations field just 1 doctor per 10,000 people. Mobile trucks and tele-health apps now zip over dirt tracks, training nurses and delivering vaccines to villages once reached only by foot. How far would you travel for health—and what invention could shorten that trek?</body_text><assets><item><asset_id>F1_A1_photo</asset_id><type>photo</type><description>Photo: A mobile clinic traveling on a dirt road.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>mobile clinic</anchor_text><url>https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/523043a1e4b05dc312ea27c6/1378909663068-OB2XV6B283NRH2SLN61E/Mobile+Clinic+%281+of+16%29.jpg?format=1500w</url></item><item><anchor_text>traveling on a dirt road</anchor_text><url>https://scontent-atl3-2.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t39.30808-6/461988683_2539865006214503_7878552211552144052_n.jpg?_nc_cat=111&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=127cfc&_nc_ohc=Ns61dvfKIa4Q7kNvgGXVB1D&_nc_zt=23&_nc_ht=scontent-atl3-2.xx&_nc_gid=ALUMs9TD29CKNluZ4XZkSN6&oh=00_AYAQeky0Pfzk_ppjeZdBFM7Wmp9HfV5eDgDvdLM-OWfSQA&oe=6761068B</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F1_A2_map</asset_id><type>map</type><description>Map: Rising, Traditions Enduring—Diverse Lives in Africa</title><body_text>Minute-long commute or millet harvest—Africa lives both futures at once. Urban dwellers have leapt from 15 % in 1960 to 44 % today, yet two-thirds of Africans still farm family plots. Money, music and messages flow back to villages, funding schools while elders guard stories and seeds. How can cities rise without letting rural wisdom fall silent?</body_text><assets><item><asset_id>F2_A1_photo</asset_id><type>photo</type><description>Photo: A busy modern African city street with tall buildings.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>A busy modern African city street</anchor_text><url>https://media.istockphoto.com/id/1333460374/photo/african-megacity-lagos-nigeria.jpg?s=1024x1024&w=is&k=20&c=1TYxrBLDIks7uEpehOKtYKh85EzXP6nbN-4Ar3aWOWs=</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F2_A2_photo</asset_id><type>photo</type><description>Photo: A small rural village with traditional homes and farmland.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>small rural village with traditional homes and farmland</anchor_text><url>https://www.matriarchafrica.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Cultural-Village-Tour-Victoria-Falls.jpg</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F2_A3_chart</asset_id><type>chart</type><description>Graph (Data Source: United Nations): A simple line graph showing how the number of people living in African cities has increased over the years.</description><data_source_label>United Nations</data_source_label><links><item><anchor_text>A simple line graph showing how the number of people living in African cities has increased over the years.</anchor_text><url>https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1EDuhwFUJBTEXQSiZp_eOYRS3SxtkQw0pE5bHJx1P-Mg/edit</url></item></links></item></assets><chart_spec><chart_type>pictogram</chart_type><pictogram_icon>house</pictogram_icon><unit_definition>1 house icon = 150 million people (total population for the reference /></chart_spec></featurette><featurette><featurette_id>AFR_FEATURETTE_3</featurette_id><number>3</number><title>How Much Can We Grow? Comparing Crop Yields Around the World</title><body_text>Food isn’t equally easy to grow so why do some fields feed more? U.S. corn averages 10 tons per hactare; Nigeria’s fields yield barely 2 tons per hectare because tractors, storage and paved roads are scarce. Sharing drought-ready seed and simple drip systems can double harvests and keep families fed. Which tool—seed, soil or road—would you add first to boost a harvest?</body_text><assets><item><asset_id>F3_A1_photo</asset_id><type>photo</type><description>Photo: A farmer in the U.S. driving a large tractor through a cornfield.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>farmer in the U.S. driving a large tractor through a cornfield</anchor_text><url>https://www.agriculture.com/thmb/cxokfdEejgW85Ors1A1UDwH6tWg=/1500x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc()/NEIllinoisoybeanHarvest-13cab4ab8b3c4a06b0d30e7a4b89f208.jpg</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F3_A2_photo</asset_id><type>photo</type><description>Photo: Farmers in Nigeria harvesting cassava by hand.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>Farmers in Nigeria harvesting</anchor_text><url>https://www.climatescorecard.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/nigeria-67.jpeg</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F3_A3_chart</asset_id><type>chart</type><description>Graph (Data Source: Food and Agriculture Organization): A bar chart showing average crop yields (in tons per hectare) of corn, rice, wheat, and cassava in different countries.</description><data_source_label>Food and Agriculture Organization</data_source_label><links><item><anchor_text>A bar chart showing average crop yields (in tons per hectare) of corn, rice, /></chart_spec></featurette><featurette><featurette_id>AFR_FEATURETTE_4</featurette_id><number>4</number><title>The Disappearing Lake—The Story of Lake Chad</title><body_text>Lake Chad once spread wider than Massachusetts but today it’s a shrinking puddle. Since 1963 the lake has lost 90 % of its water as climate warms and rivers are diverted for crops. Fishermen haul empty nets; herders clash over dusty grazing lands. Could planting trees and sharing water treaties bring this ‘vanished sea’ back to life?</body_text><assets><item><asset_id>F4_A1_image_pair</asset_id><type>image_pair</type><description>Before/After Photos (or Satellite Images): Show Lake Chad’s size in the 1960s compared to today.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>how Lake Chad’s size in the 1960s compared to today.</anchor_text><url>https://i.redd.it/g8wdspbeb5f41.jpg</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F4_A2_map</asset_id><type>map</type><description>Map: A simple map showing Lake Chad’s location and the countries around it.</description><data_source_label /><links><item><anchor_text>map</anchor_text><url>https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcQ_Jm0DfgTSOhpgh2tRZ9dWUw1TIbp08AwJH6ti2ls_-fz17s2MZ2LkqaBqkTjuZYuyMzk&usqp=CAU</url></item><item><anchor_text>Chad’s</anchor_text><url>https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/global_20170209_lake-chad.png</url></item><item><anchor_text>and</anchor_text><url>https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Megachad_en_disappearance_of_lake_chad.jpg/412px-Megachad_en_disappearance_of_lake_chad.jpg</url></item><item><anchor_text>countries</anchor_text><url>https://i.ytimg.com/vi/VYArZ50uGUE/hq720.jpg?sqp=-oaymwEhCK4FEIIDSFryq4qpAxMIARUAAAAAGAElAADIQj0AgKJD&rs=AOn4CLB1UHoj7q-FlNIb-q5DKvfZjmqDOQ</url></item></links></item><item><asset_id>F4_A3_chart</asset_id><type>chart</type><description>Graph (Data Source: NASA Earth Observatory): A line graph showing the lake’s changing size over time.</description><data_source_label>NASA Earth Observatory</data_source_label><links /></item></assets><chart_spec><chart_type>time_series_line</chart_type><metric>lake_size_over_time</metric><data /><data_links /><source_links /><status>MISSING_DATA_IN_PROVIDED_FILES</status></chart_spec></featurette></featurettes><supplemental_stats_for_app><stat><stat_id>average_distance_traveled_for_water_collection</stat_id><label>Average Distance Traveled for Water Collection</label><value_text>In some rural regions, individuals (often women and children) walk an average of 6 kilometers daily to collect water.</value_text><related_core_stat_id>access_to_clean_drinking_water</related_core_stat_id><source><file>Africa Stats.docx</file></source></stat><stat><stat_id>informal_community_support</stat_id><label>Informal Community Support</label><value_text>In many communities, informal volunteering (like communal farming and childcare) is a cultural norm, even if not officially recorded.</value_text><related_core_stat_id>volunteer_community_service_participation</related_core_stat_id><source><file>Africa Stats.docx</file></source></stat><stat><stat_id>arts_cultural_activity_participation</stat_id><label>Participation in Arts & Cultural Activities</label><value_text>Highest: Nigeria (Nollywood, music), South Africa (vibrant arts scene). Lowest: conflict-affected countries (e.g., Somalia, South Sudan).</value_text><related_core_stat_id /><source><file>Africa Cultural Domain.xlsx</file><sheet>Interesting
